author: Hulk Smash
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2018
review_content: Received the weeder from Amazon and couldn't wait to use it. The wife and I tested it on a weed in our lawn at dusk just to see if it worked. It not only pulled out the weed but also the sinister, soulless root! It ejected the lifeless carcass just like the video and even made the trademark cocking sound like a 12 gauge "shicack!".We were so pumped we told all our friends and neighbors to gather round a weed at sunset in our street side planting strip to witness the genius of mankind in all its weed destroying glory. Aim, stab, lever "shicack!". The crowd went wild, women screamed, children jumped for joy and grown men were moved to tears. After speaking a curse on all weeds left in the planting strip we placed the weeder over our mantle vowing to raze all weeds at the crack of dawn.Sunrise...The Mrs. and I dawned our gardening gear, sprayed some SPF 50 on exposed areas and grabbed the weeder. With a stoic nod and an affirming grunt the Mrs. began unleashing the dogs of garden war on the planting strip for 60 minutes. If you weren't a thriving clump of El Toro Zoysia you were ripped from your unholy seat and violently deposited into the Green Recycle Bin like a dead Christmas tree in July.Then it happened. While ripping out a clump of sleeping grass that can only be described as barbed wire with leaves, a snapping noise came from the ejection slide and the handle went soft. The jaws went limp as the weeder gasped its last breath. The sleeping grass, half ripped out of the ground sat there with a sinister smile.As we made our way back to the house friends, neighbors and loved ones lined the driveway to pay their respects to the excalibur of weeding tools. After a short eulogy, the weeder was placed back on the mantle a shadow of its former self.Fiskars Deluxe Stand-up Weeder (4-claw)You came.You conquered.You died.You'll never be forgotten.Godspeed to Valhalla where you battle weeds everyday along side your weeder brothers and sisters!

author: Ricky Mattos
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2017
review_content: WOW!! Ok everyone having issues with this product, here's the thing:I had an issue in the past also, and I guess part of it was my fault. You have to remember, that you are jamming these claws into the earth, which if it's not moist or wet enough, is going to push back on the claws and eventually either bend or break them. My advice would be, to either WAIT for it to rain, or wet your yard REALLY REALLY GOOD, then go out there and weed. When there's water on the ground from the day before, the claw will go into the earth like butter. THEN, it's a pleasure to weed out the yard and look at it! Also, I had tried this other tool in the past on my backyard where the earth is more packed in, and that's where I had an issue. Hence why I'm saying what I'm saying. Just some friendly advice.

author: 2excel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2019
review_content: This weed puller is lightweight, effective and if used per the directions should not break. I had read the concerns from others regarding breaking but then observed that most break because people use their foot on it like a Shovel. Use foot only if necessary to push straight down into the weed. But the KEY point is to let the tool do the work and tilt it toward you or the side to clamp on to the root and then you pull the weed.If you keep pounding the foot-lever you may damage or break it, if you push your foot at an angle like a shovel maybe you will also eventually break it.I had a ton of overgrown weeds and this tool made it faster than I have ever been able to clear out large parts of my yard. It only struggled with very large thick weeds because I had let them overgrow for months. With most weeds I had absolutely no issues and it worked very fast. It also has a clamp release once you pull the weed to quickly dump it into a bag or bin.Yes it does sometimes take out a large dirt clump and it works best if the soil is moist or soft, but I didn‚Äôt really think any of these were big downsides.Overall I recommend this tool and it appears this model and version is the latest from Fiskars with improvements from the previous version. As long as you don‚Äôt expect it to be as strong as a shovel, pick, or ax, it‚Äôs great and I hope I will be using it for many years to come.FWIW it does come with a pretty good warranty from Fiskars so that helps also.

author: LIMO
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2017
review_content: This was recommended by a friend so I bought it. It is probably one of the best tools I've purchased in the last 20 years. Seriously, I hope the inventor becomes a millionaire, he/she deserves it. What a fantastic, brilliant idea. Just take a large bucket, pull up the dandelion & dump it in the bucket. Once you get in a rhythm, it's fast & extremely easy. It's best to do it after you've softened the earth by watering deeply or after a soaking rain, I can see where the plastic foot part on the back can break if you're doing it in dry dirt (I tried it after the lawn had dried out & it was hard to pull them out, so I quit). I've only used it for a few hours & pulled up about 75 dandelions, but I just can't say enough about how impressed I am. The first few times, I removed some of the dirt from the pulled dandelion & put it back in the hole but then I decided to leave the hole because it's just like aerating your lawn by taking out plugs, only the holes from this tool are a little larger (about 1" vs 1/2" with aeration). The main thing is to get the dandelion puller centered over the weed so it gets the entire root out (some of the roots were so long that 2-3" were extending past the tool, but still came out intact!). I will definitely buy this tool again if it ever breaks. After fighting dandelions for decades & spending hours digging them up each year, ending up with a sore back & having the root break off & the plant re-grow (I won't use weed killer), this Fiskars Deluxe 4-claw stand-up weeder is fabulous.

review_content: Wow, just plain wow!  This thing really works, and works very easily too! review_content: Yes, this is partially made of plastic, but that keeps it lightweight and inexpensive.  Just because it's plastic, doesn't mean it's poorly designed. author: Paula D. Thomas
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2021
review_content: I have to admit this is the answer in saving your back from continuous bending to pull up weeds, especially crabgrass.  One important thing to remember in using these type weed pullers - the ground needs to be moist - very moist - if you want to have more ease in pulling up weeds.  We have combination caliche dirt which is already a problem because it is a very dry dirt that requires plenty of moisture.  Thank God we have had several rain showers to loosen up the soil.  The tool works well for a while and then it starts getting a little stubborn when you are trying to release the weed from the claws.  Sometimes the slider gets stuck and won't move until you put the tool back in the ground and step on the foot lever.  I have had to do this at least three times in a row to get the slider to release and work properly.  I have not yet had an issue with the plastic cracking.  You should not put a whole lot of pressure on the tool when you are putting it in the ground - if the ground is soft that will help alleviate that problem.  I recommend this tool because I have not yet found anything that comes up to its standards, but some improvements could be made on strengthening up the slider handle so it will stop getting stuck.  Otherwise, it's a great tool for if you want to reduce back strain and pain when pulling weeds.
title: Hands off weed pulling - terrific idea!  Less back strain - even better - Improvements needed - Yes

review_content: I bought a home in a new area last year and have been struggling with the weed situation. I was tired of crawling around pulling things out. I hated it. author: P. M. Baruch
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2018
review_content: I have used this almost exclusively to rid my garden of  violets (much as I love them) which from 3 plants have overtaken every inch.  It is hard work to pull them up by hand because of the extensive clumps and tenacious roots, to say nothing of the bending and crouching.  Provided I have watered thoroughly a few days before weeding so the soil is lightly and evenly moist, this tool works perfectly with very little effort, much easier than using a digging fork,  which also covers too big an area.  Provided the soil is neither too wet nor too dry, by holding the orange ejection bar up and giving the weeder a brisk shake I can release most of the dirt before releasing the bar and ejecting the clump into a bucket for addition to my compost bin.  Another method is to eject the clump straight into a bucket of water.  I can then sit on a bench and swish out the soil before adding the plants to the compost bin.  I find the weeder works best with more substantial plants it can get a good purchase on, hence its success with violets, so it makes sense to wait until the weeds have grown a bit.  I have not used this in a lawn, where I can imagine it would leave a largish divot.  I'm a small, elderly woman and find this tool a great help.  I have a number of Fiskar products and admire the quality and design of all of them, which is why I bought this weeder.  I'm not disappointed.

author: Alex
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2019
review_content: This weed puller works great, but the design lends itself to premature breakage. There is too much plastic used in key stress points. Best example is the plastic side plates that holds the metal pin that it is pressed into. The pin will work itself out of one side of the plastic retaining plate causing the uneven pressure to break the same. The pin is not held into the plastic by anything, so this will happen for certain - just a matter of when. It is very disappointing and aggravating. Good thing is Fiscar will replace the tool, just make certain that you take several photos, and do not throw it away until they have agreed to replace it. I made that mistake as I believed I had a sufficient number of photos that showed the damage in detail. Luckily, as a "courtesy" they agreed to replace it. review_content: Decided to purchase this after our previous weeder (a cheapy one from a local store) broke after a few hours of use. author: M. Molina
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2019
review_content: So there is another review on here, that's a humorous, funny story about how he heard a "SNAP" and the claws went limp.  I unfortunately had the same experience.  But, being the creative, self-proclaimed handyman that I am, I said, there has to be a way to fix this...So i had to determine what went wrong before I came up with a solution.  So...heres how it works....the rear tooth, pushes into the front tooth, which then pushes into both the left and right teeth.  This is the mechanism that allows all teeth to grasp the weed, right.  Well, I found out the rear tooth that is supposed to start this whole function was "sliding off" the  front tooth, therefore it never engages the rest of the teeth; hence, the left and right go limp.As you can see in my pics, I just got two dimes, and placed them as indicated.  This fills the gaps, and removes the "play" of the teeth, and aligns everything so when the mechanism closes, everything is aligned, and nothing "slides off" .  So far so good.  Im still gonna get my money back for this, but im gonna go finish my yard first.  Just a heads up to anyone having the same troubles.

review_content: This tool is perfect for a select kind of weed in certain conditions.  It works great on weeds with thick root balls or long, somewhat thick to thick tap roots in open soil. Today, Fiskar's 4-Claw Weeder arrived and--like Superman--it saved the day, ejecting all of the villains with ease. If the weed has a central root, out it comes cleanly and easily. My back thanks you, my little dog thanks you, and my long-suffering neighbors thank you!

author: Natural Expressions
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2020
review_content: I am so in love with this tool. This will forever be the perfect housewarming gift I will give all of our friends in the future. I purchased it for myself because we bought a new home that had many weeds in the yard. I was crawling around, using hand tools that kept bending and breaking weeds off at the head, leaving the root. author: xxcjtxx
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2018
review_content: I have to imagine that the unit I received was defective, because I can't see this being a usable tool in any situation. author: MamaLama
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2018
review_content: We love this weed puller. We use it to pull mostly dandelions and sticker (thistle) plants. I just have one suggestion for the manufacturer. If you don‚Äôt pull out the weed while it is young and small, it snaps off at about 1.5-2 inches below ground, leaving the base inch or two of tap root still growing. The entire weed will regenerate from that root snippet within a few weeks. Therefore I think a longer claw would go deeper and pull more out. review_content: Hastily the postman handed off my elongated package like a baton. I knew what it was. I held it like a shotgun. Cocked the box like a shotgun. date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2016
review_content: Yes it works!  Fiskars Root and Weed Remover VS Garden Weasel REVIEW: Fiskars are worth the every penny. The Fiskars can be used with one hand and both feet planted firmly on the ground.  You just place it over the weed and press it into the ground using your foot if needed to really go deep then pull back.  No dangerous balancing act.  Simple and safe for older or less balanced people.Top it all of with the metal the Weasel is made with bends if you pull back on it.  Disappointed it bent on my first 8 times using it. review_content: I bought this weeder two years ago, and thought it was time to give it a review.It has become an essential tool in my gardening arsenal. I considered giving it four stars for sturdiness, but considering its light weight, I decided it rated five stars.It arrived at high season for dandelions, and there were plenty in my lawn. I immediately started using it daily until the dandelions stopped blooming. It's fun to root out a weed and then shoot it into the basket. It leaves little divots in the lawn. Sometimes I shake the soil back into the hole, sometimes I fill it with compost, sometimes I leave it. Now in its third season, the ejector has become a little sticky and sometimes I have to use my foot to give the pedal a smart rap to eject the weed. It doesn't do well in rocky soil or where there are thick woody roots. I'm okay with all of these things. It does what it is made to do well, and when it gives out, I will immediately replace it.In two years -- three seasons, really -- my dandelion problem has dwindled remarkably. My MO is this: daily, or almost daily, I make the rounds of my lawn and garden beds, looking for dandelions, and rooting them out as I go. Doing it frequently is key because once pollinated, the flowers go to seed quickly. The flowers open throughout the day, so I usually wait until midday or afternoon to do my digging. Now, after two years' vigilance, it's become a pleasant quarter-hour task.It works best on dandelions, but I've also used it successfully on wild onions, plantain, and small dock plants, although those usually require followup with the Hori.If you're looking for a non-chemical method to control dandelions, this does an excellent job.

author: Freakonforfatty
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2014
review_content: Up until a few days ago, my biggest lawn enemy was the dreadful crabgrass, hard to kill and even harder to take out from its roots. I was using the painful method, on my knees, small crowbar and depending on the size of the crabgrass and how deep its roots are, it would take me from 5 to 10 minutes to take it out... each!!So I found the Fiskars Uproot Weed and Root Remover...I don't care how long this has been around, I just know one thing...it's what I've been looking for.As I mentioned above, my main pain on my butt has always been crabgrass, reason being, my neighbor doesn't take care of his lawn, and so it is covered with them, somehow they end up on my yard and each year is the same pain for me to get rid of them...UNTIL NOW. So let me give you a simple tip for removing crabgrass (trust me, this afternoon I removed about 20 of them):You want to make sure you know where the root ball is, so spread out any actual grass around the weed and follow the weed's branches; Crabgrass is tricky, you may think you have the Fiskars lined up to the center of the weed, but you may be wrong, crabgrass tends to flatten as it grows, and so the root ball is always off from what you may perceive as the "center" of the weed; after moths of being plagued by this pain in the butt weed, I've noticed that its roots are usually spread out, so even with this wonderful tool, you'll most likely have to go in twice or even three times to remove a single crabgrass bunch. However, the younger the weed is, the less roots it has and those usually take only one time with the Fiskars, again, if you first locate the root.Of course, not everything is perfect, and here are a couple of cons about this tool:First, a mix of plastic and metal construction. I heard and felt some straining on the tool when I was removing a very mature crabgrass, but luckily, the tool did not break.Second, and this is more of a WARNING than a con. Since you are removing the weed entirely with its roots, you will leave a HOLE in the ground, more even so when removing crabgrass, since its roots are a mix of curled up hardened roots (again, depending on maturity). So be ready to fill up the holes with dirt. If you have an infestation, I suggest you get some grass seed, some soil and patch up any big holes you leave behind.Other weeds such as dandelions and leafy weeds are easily taken out without much of an impact on the ground. Needles to say, those weeds don't have a prayer...but don't get me wrong, like the title of my review says, with Crabgrass, it is trickier, but does the job.All in all, I couldn't be happier, this is a wonderful invention and has saved me the huge pain of dealing with weeds, literal pain. My back thanks you Fiskars and my neighbors even more, 'cause I don't curse anymore...if anything, they now probably think I'm nuts, since I was literally laughing as I took each weed out! ha!

author: resi5
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2014
review_content: I've been using this for about six weeks and love it. I was worried about some reviewers' reports (perhaps in older reviews) of the foot-lever cracking, but I've had no such problems. New dandelions usually reveal themselves after a rain, so the soil has usually been quite soft when I've used this tool, and I always put my foot as close to the center (i.e., the long handle) as possible when puncturing the ground.The tricky part is making sure the "claws" surround the center of the dandelion plant. I occasionally have to create two holes (each hole is about the size of a small teacup) because I didn't quite catch the taproot at first puncture. But this is no fault of the tool.Tip: carry two buckets with you while examining your yard. (The bucket handles can hang on the foot-lever while you're carrying the tool around the yard.) You can use the first bucket for uprooted dandelions. You can use the second to carry an appropriate mixture of soil, grass seed, and starter fertilizer that go in each hole you create.Update on 4/19/15: Still working very well. No sign it will wear out or crack soon. I often have to return to a dandelion plant a few days later (when a new flower sprouts) because the tool did not get all of the plant the first time.. But this tool is so easy to use, it's no problem.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2019
review_content: This product gets 4.5 stars for pretty intuitive, for making quick work of weeds, for being fairly sturdy (metal parts where it counts), and for having a pretty elegant yet innovative design (the grab, pull, eject mechanism is pretty clever). author: Nichole
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2012
review_content: This little gadget is a gift from the Heavens that literally saved my back. I was in my yard doing the dreaded task of pulling weeds and broke the hand tool I was currently using. I tore open the box and headed outside and began my attack. Much to my pleasure it worked exactly as described. I was extremely happy with how little effort it pulled deep rooted weeds from my lawn. I will say that some of my weeds were pretty big and I wound up with several "bald" spots where it dug up a good bit of the surrounding dirt but that's my fault for letting my weeds get out of hand. I attempted to use this on a hill in my yard that has pine straw but it didn't work quite as well. Mainly because the pine straw gets in the way and you can't get deep enough to grab the root. I also had a scare when a rock got stuck in the "teeth" and I had to use a pair of pliers to dislodge it. This was not an easy task so be sure to watch out for rocks.
